hints.label: def-euler-characteristic
hints.title: Euler Characteristic (Simplicial Complex)
hints.content:
86: :label: def-euler-characteristic
87: 
88: For a simplicial complex $K$ with $V$ vertices, $E$ edges, $F$ faces (2-simplices), and $T$ tetrahedra (3-simplices) in dimension $d=3$, the **Euler characteristic** is:
89: 
90: $$
91: \chi(K) := V - E + F - T
92: 
93: $$
94: 
95: More generally, for a $d$-dimensional simplicial complex:
96: 
97: $$
98: \chi(K) := \sum_{k=0}^{d} (-1)^k n_k
99: 
100: $$
101: 
102: where $n_k$ is the number of $k$-simplices.
hints.raw_directive:

hints.label: thm-euler-delaunay
hints.title: Euler Characteristic from Delaunay Triangulation
hints.content:
108: :label: thm-euler-delaunay
109: 
110: For the walker configuration $S_t = \{x_1, \ldots, x_N\}$ at time $t$, let $\text{DT}(S_t)$ be the Delaunay triangulation. The Euler characteristic of the triangulated domain is:
111: 
112: $$
113: \chi_t := V_t - E_t + F_t - T_t
114: 
115: $$
116: 
117: where:
118: - $V_t = N$: Number of walkers (vertices)
119: - $E_t$: Number of Delaunay edges
120: - $F_t$: Number of Delaunay faces
121: - $T_t$: Number of Delaunay tetrahedra (for $d=3$)
122: 
123: **CRITICAL LIMITATION**: The Delaunay triangulation of a finite point cloud is homeomorphic to the **convex hull** of those points, NOT necessarily the underlying fitness landscape topology. For a point cloud in $\mathbb{R}^3$, the Delaunay complex of the convex hull has $\chi = 1$ regardless of whether the sampled surface has genus $g > 0$. This formula computes the Euler characteristic of the **triangulated point cloud**, not the **manifold being sampled**.
124: 
125: **To capture landscape topology**: Use α-complexes with appropriate radius thresholds or persistent homology (see § 2.3) to recover the topology of the underlying space from the sample. The Nerve Lemma guarantees that sufficiently dense sampling with appropriate filtration recovers the correct homotopy type.
126: 
127: **Valid interpretations of Delaunay $\chi_t$**:
128: 1. **Combinatorial complexity**: Number of simplices in the triangulation (algorithmic bookkeeping)
129: 2. **Gauss-Bonnet verification**: Check $\sum_i \delta_i = 2\pi \chi_t$ for internal consistency
130: 3. **NOT valid**: Inferring genus, detecting topological phase transitions, or measuring landscape topology directly from Delaunay $\chi$ alone
131: 
132: **Computational Complexity**: $O(|\text{simplices}|)$ for scanning all simplices in the triangulation. In $\mathbb{R}^d$, a Delaunay triangulation of $N$ points contains $O(N)$ simplices for $d=2$, $O(N)$ for $d=3$ (typically), but up to $\Theta(N^{\lceil d/2 \rceil})$ in the worst case. For practical walker configurations in $\mathbb{R}^3$, the simplex count is usually $O(N)$, making the Euler characteristic computation linear in the number of walkers.

hints.label: rem-euler-dimensions
hints.title: Euler Characteristic for Different Dimensions
hints.content:
138: :label: rem-euler-dimensions
139: 
140: **For $d=2$** (triangulated surfaces):
141: 
142: $$
143: \chi = V - E + F
144: 
145: $$
146: 
147: **Standard values**:
148: - Sphere: $\chi = 2$
149: - Torus: $\chi = 0$
150: - Klein bottle: $\chi = 0$
151: - Disk: $\chi = 1$
152: 
153: **For $d=4$** (4D simplicial complexes):
154: 
155: $$
156: \chi = V - E + F - T + P
157: 
158: $$

hints.label: thm-discrete-gauss-bonnet-topology
hints.title: Discrete Gauss-Bonnet Theorem
hints.content:
168: :label: thm-discrete-gauss-bonnet-topology
169: 
170: For a **closed** triangulated polyhedral surface $P$ (simplicial 2-complex **without boundary**), the sum of deficit angles (see [curvature.md](curvature.md) § 1.1) equals:
171: 
172: $$
173: \sum_{i \in \text{vertices}} \delta_i = 2\pi \chi(P)
174: 
175: $$
176: 
177: where $\delta_i$ is the deficit angle at vertex $i$ and $\chi(P)$ is the Euler characteristic.
178: 
179: **Boundary case**: For surfaces with boundary $\partial M$, the formula becomes:
180: 
181: $$
182: \sum_{i \in \text{vertices}} \delta_i + \int_{\partial M} \kappa_g \, ds = 2\pi \chi(M)
183: 
184: $$
185: 
186: where $\kappa_g$ is the geodesic curvature along the boundary curves and $ds$ is the arc length element. See [curvature.md](curvature.md) § 1.1 for full treatment of boundary contributions.
187: 
188: **Consequence**: The total integrated Gaussian curvature is determined by topology:
189: 
190: $$
191: \int_M K \, dA = 2\pi \chi(M)
192: 
193: $$
hints.raw_directive:
165: The Euler characteristic is deeply connected to curvature via the **Gauss-Bonnet theorem**, which bridges local geometry and global topology.

174:

176: 
177: where $\delta_i$ is the deficit angle at vertex $i$ and $\chi(P)$ is the Euler characteristic.
178: 
179: **Boundary case**: For surfaces with boundary $\partial M$, the formula becomes:
180: 
181: $$
182: \sum_{i \in \text{vertices}} \delta_i + \int_{\partial M} \kappa_g \, ds = 2\pi \chi(M)
183: 
184: $$
185: 
186: where $\kappa_g$ is the geodesic curvature along the boundary curves and $ds$ is the arc length element. See [curvature.md](curvature.md) § 1.1 for full treatment of boundary contributions.

hints.label: rem-euler-characteristic-scutoid-connection
hints.title: Euler Characteristic and Scutoid Cells
hints.content:
199: :label: rem-euler-characteristic-scutoid-connection
200: 
201: Each individual scutoid cell $\mathcal{S}$ is topologically homeomorphic to a **3-ball** (a convex polyhedron), and therefore has Euler characteristic:
202: 
203: $$
204: \chi(\mathcal{S}) = 1
205: 
206: $$
207: 
208: regardless of its combinatorial structure (number of faces, mid-level vertices, etc.).
209: 
210: The **scutoid index** $\chi_{\text{scutoid}}$ defined in [14_scutoid_geometry_framework.md](14_scutoid_geometry_framework.md) is a **separate topological invariant** that measures cloning activity at mid-level vertices, not the Euler characteristic of the cell itself. See {prf:ref}`prop-euler-characteristic-scutoid` for the relationship between $\chi_{\text{scutoid}}$ and the combinatorial structure of scutoid faces.
211: 
212: **Critical**: The Euler characteristic of the entire spacetime tessellation is **not** the sum of individual cell Euler characteristics. The global Euler characteristic must be computed directly from the full Delaunay triangulation using {prf:ref}`thm-euler-delaunay`:
213: 
214: $$
215: \chi_{\text{total}}(t) = V_t - E_t + F_t - T_t
216: 
217: $$
